Theorem 1. Eulerâ€™s Theorem. Let $a \in \mathbb{Z}$ and $n\in\mathbb{N}$. If$\gcd(a, n)=1$, then $a^{\phi(n)} \equiv 1 \pmod{n}$.
Lemma 1. Let $x, y, a, b \in\mathbb{Z}^{+}$ such that $\gcd(a, b)=1$. If $x\equiv y \pmod{a}$ and $x\equiv y \pmod{b}$,then $x\equiv y \pmod{ab}$.
Theorem 2. Let $n = pq$ where p and q are distinct prime integers, let $m \in\{0,1, 2,â€¦,n âˆ’ 1\},e, d \in\mathbb{Z}$ such that $ed\equiv 1 \pmod{\phi(n)}$, and let $c \equiv m^e \pmod{n}$. Then $c^{d}\equiv m \pmod{n}$

Theorem 3. The order of the General Linear Group $GL_2(Z_p)$ is given by $|GL_{2}(Z_{p})| = (p^{2} âˆ’ 1)(p^{2} âˆ’ p),$where p is a prime integer.

$Proof$. Let $S = \left\{ egin{bmatrix}a&b\c&d\end{bmatrix}:a,b,c,d\in\mathbb{Z}_{p} ight\}$ï¼Œæ³¨æ„åˆ°$GL_{2}(\mathbb{Z}_{p})\subset S$ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å°è¯•ä»æ‰€æœ‰å¯èƒ½ä¸­å‡å»ä¸å±äºè¯¥ç¾¤çš„çŸ©é˜µæ¥è®¡ç®—æ€»çŸ©é˜µæ•°é‡ã€‚

Theorem 4. Lagrangeâ€™s Theorem. Let $H$ be a subgroup of a finite group $G$. Then $|H|$ divides $|G|$.We also require the following lemma.
Lemma 2. Let $n = pq$ where $p$ and $q$ are distinct prime integers. If $M\in GL_2(\mathbb{Z}_n)$, then $M \in GL_2(\mathbb{Z}_p)$ and $M \in GL_2(\mathbb{Z}_q)$.

Theorem 5. Let $n = pq$ where p and q are distinct prime numbers, let $M\in GL_2(\mathbb{Z}_n)$ be a matrix made up of nonnegative integers less than n, let $g_{p} = |GL_2(\mathbb{Z}_{p})|= (p^2âˆ’1)(p^2âˆ’p)$ and $g_q = |GL_2(\mathbb{Z}_{q})|=(q^{2}âˆ’1)(q^{2}-q)$ and define $g=g_{p}g_{q}$ . Further let $e, d \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}$ such that $ed\equiv \pmod{g}$, and let $C\equiv M^{e}\pmod{n}$. Then $C^{d}\equiv M\pmod{g}$.

$Proof.$å‡è®¾å·²ç»å®šä¹‰äº†ä¸Šè¿°æ‰€æœ‰å˜é‡å’ŒçŸ©é˜µï¼Œæœ‰$C^{d}\equiv M^{ed}\equiv M\pmod{n}$ã€‚

$\because c1=(2p+3q)^{e1}$ mod n
$\therefore c1=((2p)^{e1}+(3q)^{e1})$ mod n
$\therefore c1^{e2}=((2p)^{K}+(3q)^{K})$ mod n
åŒç†
$\because c2=(5p+7q)^{e1}$ mod n
$\therefore c2=((5p)^{e2}+(7q)^{e2})$ mod n
$\therefore c2^{e1}=((5p)^{K}+(7q)^{K})$ mod n

$\therefore c2^{e1}3^{K}-c1^{e2}7^{K}=p^{K}(15^{K}-14^{K})=p^{K}$
$c1^{e2}5^{K}-c2^{e1}2^{K}=q^{K}(15^{K}-14^{K})=q^{K}$

$\therefore p=gcd(c2^{e1}3^{K}-c1^{e2}7^{K},n)$
$q=gcd(c1^{e2}5^{K}-c2^{e1}2^{K},n)$
